text: , also called Naniwa no Tsu, was an ancient Imperial capital of Japan in the 7th and 8th centuries. It was located in present-day Osaka.Nussbaum, Louis- Frédéric. (2002). "Naniwa" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 697. ==History== Naniwa was founded by Emperor Temmu in 683. After 745, the capital moved to Heijō- kyō. ===Timeline=== * 683: Temmu establishes Naniwa * 744 (Tenpyō 16): Emperor Shōmu and the court moved to Naniwa, which then became the new capital.Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du Japon, p. 71. * 745 (Tenpyō 17): Shōmu built a palace named Shigaraki no MiyaHall, John Whitney et al. (1993). The Cambridge History of Japan, pp. 42–44. * 745 (Tenpyō 17): The court and the capital moves to Heijō Kyō. ===Archeology=== In 1957, traces of ancient palaces were found.Stone, Peter G. and Philippe G. Planel. (1999). The Constructed Past: Experimental Archaeology, Education and the Public, p. 68–70. Other archaeological site was discovered in 2006.Osaka Museum of History, "Recent Archaeological Discoveries in Osaka 2007" .
